metadata.title: Ganglion Cyst (Neuroma)
anatomical location body part affected: Can be located throughout the body, usually adjacent to or within joints and tendons. Most commonly located on the wrist, foot, and ankle.(22)Less commonly, cysts have also been reported in the knee,(21) especially years following ACL reconstruction(23)
description: Ganglion cysts are common, benign soft tissue masses.(21) They are fluid-filled  subcutaneous sacs arising from joint capsule (collagen), ligament, bursa, or tendon sheath. Although the name neuroma suggests nerve origin, ganglion cysts usually are extraneural(1)

ICD-10 codes.M67.4: ganglion; ganglion of joint or tendon (sheath) (ICD codes are provided for the reader’s reference, not for billing purposes)

reimbursement: No specific issue or information regarding reimbursement has been identified
presentation signs and symptoms: Patients often present with a visible and palpable lump, concerned that it might be a tumor
It is unusual for a patient to complain that the ganglion cyst causes a functional limitation

Cysts are most common on the dorsum of the wrist, and present as a single round, smooth, raised lump –The cyst usually is firm, fluctuant, and not tender on palpation –Average cyst sizes have been reported to be from 0.5 cm to 3 cm. The size may have changed over time, enlarging with increased joint use and shrinking with less use(1) –Cysts typically are sacs filled with clear, sticky, thick fluid –The cyst itself is not usually painful, but may compress structures to cause pain, tenderness, and/or neuritis. –In rare cases, weakness and restricted ROM may occur(1) –Occult ganglion cysts trapped beneath the extensor retinaculum are not visible or palpable but may ache when pressure within the ganglion increases,(3) or they may cause significant pain(1,4)
Prevalence of wrist ganglia in patients presenting with some discomfort has been reported to be 19%(1)
Ganglion cysts at other joints are more rare and the clinical manifestations are variable and nonspecific
Prevalence of ganglion cysts in the dorsum of the ankle has been reported to be 5.6%(1)  Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors
contraindications precautions to test: Refer to physician or surgeon if the cyst is highly tender, nonmobile (attached), or impingement/entrapment is suspected
Refer to physician if cyst is associated with symptoms of neuritis

causes:: The etiology is largely unknown. Ganglion cysts usually are insidious in onset but may arise suddenly(2)–Usually located near joints under continuous mechanical stress. Consequently, repetitive or strenuous use of the involvedjoint may contribute to their formation or enlargement(2)–Trauma to the joint has been proposed as a cause of cyst formation, but the majority of patients cannot recall a specifictrauma that precipitated the cyst(1) and the literature does not support trauma as an important etiological factor(4)
pathogenesis:: Pathogenesis is unclear. Several theories have been proposed to explain the pathoanatomic mechanism of cyst formation–Ganglion cysts may develop from connective tissue by mucoid degeneration and disintegration of collagen fibers(4,5)–They may occur when fluid leaks out of a joint or tendon sheath by synovial herniation or expansion(2)–Microtrauma causing stretching of capsular tissues and ligaments may stimulate production of hyaluronic acid, thepredominant component of the fluid within the cyst(4)–Ganglion cysts usually are connected with the joint.(5) The most common joint location is between the scaphoid andlunate of the hand, originating from the scapholunate ligament(6,7)–When multiple ganglion cysts form, usually they are connected by a stalk(1,4,25)
risk factors:: Definitive evidence does not exist regarding specific risk factors for ganglion cysts; however, trauma, repetitive or forcefulactivities of the joint, and a previous ganglion cyst likely increase the risk of developing subsequent cysts(1)
Ganglion cysts occur in all age groups but are more common in young adults, in females 3 times more often than males(1)
There are no known occupational risk factors(1)

overall contraindications precautions: Ganglion cysts may compress surrounding structures. Thorough examination of nerves, blood vessels, and other surrounding structures is essential for determining the secondary effects of a ganglion cyst. If impingement or entrapment on these structures is noted, the cyst may need to be surgically removed
Crushing a ganglion cyst is not recommended, as it often results in cyst recurrence and may injure the affected area
Refer to physician if diagnosis of ganglion cyst requires confirmation

contraindications precautions to examina: Refer to physician or surgeon if the cyst is highly tender, nonmobile (attached), or impingement/entrapment is suspected
Refer to physician if cyst is associated with symptoms of neuritis

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: How long has the cyst been present? Does the cyst vary in size? If so, what makes the cyst bigger or smaller? Increase in size may be related to joint usage

course of treatment.medical management: Medical management No treatment is necessary if the cyst is not growing progressively and the patient is asymptomatic Cyst aspiration typically is done under local anesthesia with a 16-gauge  needle in the physician’s office.(17)Cyst aspiration or steroid injection may be tried, but recurrence is common and the evidence supporting steroid injections is weak.(17)It is becoming more common to use ultrasound (US) guidance with cyst aspiration to allow for direct visualization and potentially greater success.(18,24)Palmar ganglia should only be aspirated with US guidance due to an increased risk of damage to the neurovascular structures from blind aspiration.(17) Aspiration may be unsuccessful in cases of hardened mucoid(1)  Recurrence of a ganglion cyst is common following surgical removal and studies indicate there is no difference in pain reduction, weakness, and stiffness when cysts are surgically removed compared to aspiration(1) Injection of autologous fibrin sealants into aspirated cysts to seal cyst walls together and prevent recurrence has been reported(8)
course of treatment.medications: Medications for current illness/injury No medications are found to be effective at eradicating a ganglion cyst; however, physicians often use steroid injections to treat ganglion cysts(1)
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic testing is recommended to rule out neoplasm (9)

Although MRI may be used to confirm a ganglion cyst, the cyst often is discovered incidentally by an MRI done for a different reason. MRI and ultrasonography may also provide information regarding the compression of nerves, blood vessels, and other surrounding soft tissue structures (10)
Ultrasonography is considered accurate and is less costly than MRI for distinguishing solid tumors from cystic lesions and for specifically diagnosing ganglion cysts
Typically there are no findings on X-rays,  but increased remodeling of bone may be seen in some cases(5)
Rarely, a biopsy may be needed if neoplasm is suspected
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether they help
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had occupational or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful. Patients with intraarticular cysts at the knee or hip may report symptoms that failed to respond to treatment for other conditions at those joints(10,11)

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Aggravating/easing factors  (and length of time each item is performed before the symptoms come on or are eased). Do any activities increase or decrease symptoms or size of ganglion cyst?
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms -Sixty percent to 70% of hand and wrist ganglions are located on the dorsal wrist and 1520%  are on the palmar wrist. Cysts can also be located on dorsum of the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joint(1)
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms (constant vs. intermittent, sharp, dull, aching, burning, numbness, tingling) -Ganglion cysts typically are asymptomatic except for the fact that they can change in size -In some cases, ganglion cysts can cause local nerve compression resulting in pain or ROM restriction(1) -Acute ulnar neuropathy at the wrist is uncommon but can be caused by a ganglion cyst in Guyon’s canal(19)
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much). Pain may or may not be present
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (A.M., mid-day,  P.M., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Document number of wakings/night, if applicable
history of present illness.other symptoms: Ask if the patient has any other symptoms that indicate compression of nearby nerves or blood vessels Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes __ No __ -If Yes, describe ________________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Is there any history of osteoarthritis? Was there a traumatic event involving the affected joint? Previous history of ganglion cyst?
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask patient about other problems, including diabetes, cancer, heart disease, osteoarthritis, complications of pregnancy, psychiatric disorders, and orthopedic disorders
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs)

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Does the patient participate in repetitive work or leisure activities involving the affected joint, or any forceful activities of the affected joint, such as keyboarding, yoga, or gymnastics?
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Does the patient have any functional limitations resulting from the cyst? Normally, ganglion cysts cause no functional limitations

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting)
relevant tests and measures.circulation: Distal pulses should be normal, but should be assessed to rule out compression of the artery by the ganglion cystIf applicable, monitor for redness, foul smell, and swelling around surgical sitesAssess affected joint for additional injury if development of a ganglion cyst is related to traumaAssess coordination of hand, if appropriate. Ganglion cysts at the fibular head have also been reported as a cause of peroneal neuropathy and foot drop.(21) Assess upper/lower extremity as appropriate
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Assess strength of affected extremity. For hand, utilize dynamometer
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Determine active and passive ROM to assess function of the affected joint. Assess for pain during ROM
relevant tests and measures.sensory testing: The dermatome scan should be normal; however, compression of a nerve by the ganglion cyst may result in paresthesia, neuropathic pain,(21) and sensory loss(21)
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: –For the hand, Disabilities of the Arm, Shoulder and Hand (DASH) Outcome Measurethe ganglion glows when a penlight is shone through it (1,13)

contraindications precautions: Use caution with patients who are hypertensive, as cold can cause a transient increase in blood pressure; discontinue treatment if there is an elevation in blood pressure
Use caution with patients who are hypersensitive to cold
Avoid aggressive treatment with cold modalities over an acute wound
Use of cryotherapy with patients who have an aversion to cold may be counterproductive if being used to promote muscle relaxation and decrease pain(14)
other: In the past, clinicians crushed ganglion cysts by smashing them. However, this technique is not recommended, as it often results in cyst recurrence and may injure the affected area
Moist heat or cryotherapy may be trialed for pain relief(14)

Contraindications to heating modalities  include application over areas with decreased sensation, vascular insufficiency, recent or potential hemorrhage, malignancy, acute inflammation, or infection. Do not use heat over areas where heat rubs or liniments have been recently used. Do not use heat if unable to determine sensory deficits in patients with cognitive deficits or if a language barrier is present(14)

Contraindications to cryotherapy  include Raynaud’s syndrome, medical instability, cryoglobulinemia, cold urticaria, and paroxysmal cold hemoglobinuria. Avoid applying cold over superficial nerves, areas of diminished sensation, poor circulation, or slow-healing  wounds(14)

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: Presence of a ganglion cyst on the dorsum of the wrist or other joint. Postoperative rehabilitation for patients who have had cyst removal with joint surgery. Cases with pain, paresthesia, weakness, and restricted ROM
assessment plan of care.rule out: Rule out Lipoma(6) Fibroma Epidermoid inclusion cyst Osteochondroma Hemangioma Gout Rheumatoid nodule Radial artery aneurysm Extensor tenosynovitis(6) –Flexor halluces longus tendinopathy has been reported to occur concurrently with ganglion cysts in the foot(21) Giant cell tumor of tendon sheath(6) Carpal boss(6) (painful bony prominence on dorsal hand) Scapholunate ligament injury/strain(6) Kienböck’s disease (avascular necrosis of lunate)(6) Sarcoma(1) Hamartoma(1) Osteophyte(1) Tarsal tunnel syndrome(22) when foot/Achilles pain is present
prognosis: Approximately 58% of dorsal wrist ganglia(15) and 50% of palmar wrist ganglia were found to resolve spontaneously within 6 years(16)
The recurrence rate following surgical excision of a ganglion cyst is reported to be 39–50%(6,15)

Authors of a 6-year  study comparing blind aspiration, surgical excision, and no intervention concluded that neither aspiration nor surgical excision provided a definitive long-term  benefit over no intervention. The only benefit of surgery was early resolution of the cosmetic appearance of the ganglion(15)

Results from studies are mixed regarding the recurrence rate following aspiration. The recurrence rate following aspiration of a ganglion cyst is as high as 80%, but serial aspiration yields results with a lower rate of recurrence of about 20%.Splinting after the procedure may increase the success rate. Mucous cysts can be aspirated, but the recurrence rate is more than 50% and pain may not subside if due to underlying osteoarthritis(17)
There is a higher rate of resolution in children; up to 80% of ganglion cysts in children resolve spontaneously(1)

Researchers conducting a case study of an elite swimmer in Turkey reported return to a sport-specific  training program 6 weeks after surgical excision of a ganglion cyst in the foot. No recurrence of pain/cyst was found at 6-months  follow-up(20)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Refer patient to physician as indicated; to occupational therapist (OT) for wrist splint as indicated
treatment summary: Infrequently, patients may be referred for physical therapy to manage the secondary symptoms resulting from a ganglion cyst
Typically, physical therapy will be indicated for problems within the affected joint occurring simultaneously with a ganglion cyst

Treatment of symptoms and secondary effects of the ganglion cyst may also be addressed. This may include –the use of physical modalities (moist heat, ice) for relief of pain –therapeutic exercises to strengthen and stretch the affected joint –manual therapy to increase joint ROM

Physical therapy may be indicated following surgical excision. The main treatment interventions involve wound care and edema and scar management. Therapeutic exercise to increase strength and passive ROM (PROM)/stretching to  increase ROM may facilitate return to prior level of function. These interventions would need to be tailored to the specific joint affected by the ganglion cyst, and would vary depending on the type of surgery required to excise the cyst (i.e., arthroscopic, open) . Problem Goal Intervention Expected Progression Home Program Presence of ganglion cystPhysical therapy is not generally indicated for the treatment of a ganglion cyst unless there are secondary symptoms. If a patient presents with this condition, the goals would be to identify the ganglion cyst and refer to physician for further evaluation and treatmentTherapeutic strategies _ Identify ganglion cyst and refer to physician for further evaluation and treatmentN/A N/A Secondary symptoms of ganglion cyst (pain, paresthesia, decreased strength and ROM)Resolve secondary symptomsPhysical modalities _ Moist heat or ice for relief of pain _ _ Splinting _ Wrist splint may help symptoms _ _ Therapeutic exercises _ Strengthen and stretch the affected joint, and manual therapy to increase joint ROM. Because a ganglion cyst can occur in any joint, specific treatment must be tailored to each individual caseN/A Instruct patient in proper use of splint and heat/cold for pain relief _ _ Continue prescribed exercises at home  Postsurgical symptoms _ _ Decreased ability to perform ADLs, functional mobility, self-careResolve pain, ROM, strength and functional limitations and promote wound healing _ _ Improve ADLs, functional mobility, and self-careWound care _ Address skin integrity issues if needed (wound care, edema, and scar management) _ _ Therapeutic exercise _ Strengthening and passive ROM / stretching to the specific joint affected by the ganglion cyst _ _ Functional training _ Dexterity/coordination activities, ADL and self-care trainingN/A _ _ Progress patient as appropriateInstruct patient in independent wound and edema management _ _ Continue prescribed exercises at home _ _ Provide written and verbal instructions for home program .

desired outcomes: Resolution of ganglion cyst and any secondary deficits resulting from the ganglion cyst or cyst excision

maintenance or prevention: Avoidance of repetitive or forceful activity of the affected joint
patient education: Ganglion Cyst.
